dc:title: Ants like flower nectar ( Costa Rica).
dc:creator: Haber W.
dc:description: Janzen (1977) speculated that ants generally do not feed on floral nectars in lowland tropical habitats because the nectars contain repugnant, indigestible or toxic chemicals. Numerous ant species are reported taking floral nectar from 27 plant species in primarily a lowland dry forest habitat in Costa Rica. Floral nectar from 21 plants was readily accepted by ants in all but two cases. Some of the nectars were known to contain phenolic compounds and alkaloids. Little evidence was found to support Janzen's speculation. -Authors

dc:title: The abundance and seasonality of forest canopy birds on Barro Colorado Island, Panama ( Dendroica castanea).
dc:creator: Greenberg R.
dc:description: The outer canopy of a lowland tropical forest on Barro Colorado Island, Panama, has a less buffered microclimate and more seasonal leaf phenology than the understory. The canopy avifauna shares many species with scrubby second growth; many common canopy species were also found frequently in more open areas. Rarest visitors to the canopy were primarily those from lower strata. Most common species were omnivorous; restricted insectivores were poorly represented when compared to lower strata. This distribution is correlated with a taxonomic shift from the antbird-woodcreeper-dominated understory to a tanager-dominated canopy avifauna. A majority of common canopy species was significantly seasonal in abundance, the most seasonal resident species tending to be the omnivores. Two sources of overall fluctuation in birds using the outer canopy were an influx of small omnivorous tanagers in the early dry to early wet season, and the presence of temperature-zone migrants, mainly Dendroica castanea, from late wet through the dry season. -from Author

dc:title: Wind dispersal of Panamanian hairstreak butterflies ( Lepidoptera: Lycaenidae) and its evolutionary significance.
dc:creator: Robbins R.
dc:description: Evidence is presented that hairstreak butterflies in the Republic of Panama are dispersed by seasonal trade winds (late December- early April) from the northwest. Consequences of dispersal of Panamanian hairstreaks on their tendency to differentiate geographically and on their rate of allopatric speciation are discussed.-from Authors

dc:title: Infrared reflectance in chameleons ( Chamaeleonidae) from Kenya.
dc:creator: Dodd C.K.
dc:description: Chamaeleo hohnelii, schubotzi, gracilis and fischeri were photographed in Kenya shortly after capture using infrared film. Two species (gracilis, fischeri) reflected infrared light; the others did not. Infrared reflectance may be a thermoregulatory mechanism or may allow the animal to blend in with its surroundings for both avoiding predators and capturing prey.-from Author

dc:title: Polymorphic mimicry of polistine wasps by a neotropical neuropteran.
dc:creator: Opler P.
dc:description: Climaciella brunnea is a polymorphic mantispid studied in Guanacaste Province, Costa Rica. Five distinct color morphs were sampled, each being a presumed Batesian mimic of a different polistine wasp. The proportion of morphs varied between 3 separate localities and presumably reflected the differential abundance and aggressiveness of models at each site. Frequency-dependent selection via differential predation is probably responsible for the evolution of the polymorphism and would maintain different morph frequencies at different sites.-from Author

dc:title: White-sand vegetation of Brazilian Amazonia ( caatinga).
dc:creator: Anderson A.B.
dc:description: The described vegetation type, 'Amazon caatinga', is distinguished by its white-sand soil, scleromorphic physiognomy, and unusual floristic composition. The scleromorphic physiognomy of the caatinga indicates a lack of nutrients and/or periodic water deficiencies in the soil. Extreme edaphic conditions and the insularity of these sites have probably acted as powerful selective forces, generating a biota characteristically low in diversity and high in endemism. Numerous endemics may currently face extinction due to widespread burning. Repeated fires on white-sand sites result in the effective arrest of succession.-from Author

dc:title: Foraging patterns of black rats across a desert-montane forest gradient in the Galapagos Islands ( Rattus rattus).
dc:creator: Clark D.A.
dc:description: The foraging behavior of Rattus rattus was studied in 4 different Galapagos habitats: thorn scrub, savanna, montane scrub, and montane forest. Plant foods comprised an average of 80% of stomach contents, but animal food occurred in at least 81% of the rats in each population, and reproduction was correlated with a high level of animal food in the diet. Although the rats fed on an extremely broad range of plant and animal foods, they were very selective feeders, discriminating among plant species and among parts of plants. Fruits and seeds were preferred foods, and in most cases the seeds were destroyed. These introduced rodents are probably having many severe effects on the Galapagos flora and fauna.-from Author

dc:title: The tropical rain forest canopy: a method providing total access.
dc:creator: Perry D.R.
dc:description: An aerial rope network was constructed, using emergent trees as supports, which provides access to a large volume of tropical rain forest from ground level to above the canopy's upper surface.-from Authors Dept Biology, University of California, Los Angeles, California 90024, U.S.A.

dc:title: An association between two neotropical spiders ( Araneae: Uloboridae and Tengellidae).
dc:creator: Fincke O.
dc:description: At a lowland wet forest site in Costa Rica, the uloborid Philoponella vicina builds orb webs among the frame lines of the platform web constructed by Tengella radiata, the much larger tengellid species. These uloborids actively choose to build in T. radiata webs. 'Associated' uloborids persisted at a web site significantly longer than 'solo' uloborids. Prey capture was significantly greater for the 'associated' uloborids than for 'solo' spiders. The association appears to be commensal.-from Author

dc:title: The production of dilute nectars by hummingbird and honeyeater flowers.
dc:creator: Pyke G.
dc:description: A survey of data from tropical and temperate regions confirms that nectars of hummingbird and honeyeater flowers are dilute, especially relative to nectars of bee flowers. These data are used, along with theoretical considerations, to examine three recently proposed hypotheses to explain low concentration of hummingbird nectars. None of the quantitative or qualitative predictions of these hypotheses appears to be upheld. -from Authors

dc:title: Frugivory in some migrant tropical forest wood warblers.
dc:creator: Greenberg R.
dc:description: Three species of wood warblers (Parulidae), the bay-breasted Dendroica castanea, chestnut-sided D. pensylvanica and Tennessee Vermivora peregrina warblers, eat fruit in the winter on Barro Colorado Island, Panama. A seasonal pattern of frugivory was observed for the two congeners (bay-breasted and chestnut-sided), both species displaying a strong peak in frugivory in the late dry season. They also were highly frugivorous earlier in the winter, during a general fruiting low, in response to the fruit crops of Lindackeria laurina and Casearia spp. Chestnut-sided and bay-breasted warblers occur commonly at only a few species of fruiting trees, mainly Miconia argentea and Lindackeria laurina. These trees were visited by warblers far out of proportion to the relative abundance of warblers among small omnivorous forest birds. Lindackeria was visited almost exclusively by warblers. Lindackeria appeared to be specialized for dispersal by warblers to a degree not reported for any other migrant-dispersed fruits in the tropics. Chestnut-sided warblers defend small territories, a circumstance which makes preferred fruiting trees an undependable food supply. Bay-breasted warblers aggregate from a large area to feed on preferred trees, so fruit supply is more predictable. Bay-breasted and Tennessee warblers (and other migrants such as red-eyed vireo Vireo olivaceus) are far more intraspecifically gregarious than are most tropical forest residents. It is possibly the tendency to visit fruiting trees in large flocks that makes migrants potentially good dispersers for some plants.-from Author

dc:title: Driptips and splash erosion.
dc:creator: Williamson G.
dc:description: Driptips are shown to be related to the size of water drops running off leaves, but they had little effect on total rate of runoff. -from Author

dc:title: Consumption of leaves by herbivores in mixed mangrove stands ( Xylocarpus).
dc:creator: Johnstone I.M.
dc:description: Up to 20% of the mangrove leaf blade enters the food web via herbivore consumption. Quantity of leaf material eaten could not be correlated with any of the following parameters; species diversity (species number), distance of the plant from the upper tidal limit, plant density, season, energy value of the leaves, presence of 'protective' ants, chloride content of leaves, or pollution (high nitrogen levels). Recently leaved Xylocarpus were the only plants with no leaf damage. Damage from leaf to leaf was extremely variable and obscured between-plant and, in most instances, between-species differences. -from Author Biology Dept, PO Box 4820, Univ PO NCD, Papua, New Guinea.

dc:title: Seasonality in tropical hermit crab reproduction in the Bay of Panama.
dc:creator: Bertness M.
dc:description: The three sympatric hermit crab species studied reveal reproductive patterns mediated by their supply of shells, which are in limited supply. Crabs with shells large enough to allow growth put effort into growth, while crabs in shells too small to permit growth allocate more time and effort to reproduction. Dry-season upwelling increases the food supply to these hermit crabs and results in increased hermit crab growth rates. The increased size of dry-season crabs in the same suite of shells as the smaller rainy-season crabs triggers increased reproductive activity during the dry season. -from Author

dc:title: Patterns of herbivory in a tropical deciduous forest.
dc:creator: Janzen D.
dc:description: In the lowland deciduous and riparian evergreen forests of Guanacaste Province, Costa Rica, insect seed predators are highly host-specific and display a variety of traits suggesting that the ways they use hosts are not randomly distributed. Vertebrate seed predators may feed on many species of seeds over the course of a year or within the animal population, but, at any one time or with any one individual, strong facultative host-specificity occurs. Vertebrates have a variety of species-specific behaviors that suggest specialization to overcome the defenses of particular seed species. Even the dispersal agents kill seeds as they pass through their guts, and the details of seed-defecation patterns should be important to the seed. Leaf-eating caterpillars seem to be either specialized on one or a few species of plants, or spread over many. Defoliations and severe herbivory occur with many plant species in various seasons or years. Herbivory by large herbivores is probably trivial compared to that of insects. The defenses that the large herbivores have to overcome may well have been selected for by both insects and extinct Pleistocene large herbivores. Many of the animal-plant interactions in this forest are probably not coevolved, but those that are coevolved are difficult to distinguish from those that are not. -from Author
